newsitem.title: ITALY: German economic advisor Hax criticises gold plan.
newsitem.headline: German economic advisor Hax criticises gold plan.

text.p: Leading German economist Herbert Hax said in an Italian newspaper interview on Tuesday that Bonn's controversial plan to revalue gold reserves was dangerous and urged a delay to the launch of the single European currency.

"There is always a certain danger when politicians want to subordinate monetary policy to their overall economic policy," Hax, chairman of the German councillor of advisors known as the "five wise men", told La Repubblica daily.
"The (German) government can tell the Bundesbank to revalue its reserves but it is dangerous to finance public deficits like that," he added.

A row between Germany's independent Bundesbank and Bonn erupted last week after Finance Minister Theo Waigel unveiled plans to revalue national gold and currency reserves and use a part of the proceeds to fill holes in the state budget.

The Bundesbank said the move could be viewed as creative accounting designed to ensure Germany met criteria laid down in the Maastricht Treaty for founder members of the single currency, which is due to be launched in 1999.
Hax said the timeframe for European economic and monetary union should be pushed back as countries were failing to meet the stiff economic targets to join the single euro currency.

"I believe a delay in the euro would be the most realistic solution. All the problems come from the decision to interpret the criteria rigidly, even now, and to stick to a rigid and definitive timeframe," Hax said.

"Both things are no longer possible in today's conditions. From this comes the intention of the (German) government to use the proceeds from a revaluation of gold reserves of the Bundesbank in the 1997 budget."
He said profits from any revaluations should not be put on state accounts until 1998.
